reviewText:
Early Access Review

RPG MO truely is a kickback to old-school online RPGs.  The graphics and gameplay are very nostalgic and addictive, and I can honestly say that it wasn't hard to put a couple hundred hours into this game.  With that being said,  I can't recommend it -- why, you might ask?  It may sound cliche, but, that's right, you got it, the management. :/

(*As an initial note, I have never been muted or banned in the entirety of my gameplay.*)

I'm not going to generalize, because the majority of the mods (who simply love and play the game enough to volunteer their time to help keep the peace) are nice folks, and very level-headed.  However, it's impossible to play the game for a decent amount of time without witnessing at least couple of them (who shall remain unnamed), show an insane amount of bias towards certain players they like (who shall also remained unnamed), or act out in entirely immature ways that just cannot be respected.

This wouldn't be such a problem, except they are immune to criticism.  Openly voicing your concern will get you muted/banned (as I've witnessed happen on many occasions), and reporting said behavior to the developers is useless, because they also show favoritism and immaturity.  If you take a gander through posts and replies that the developer had made to reviews, you can view this child-like temperament in action.

It's a damn shame, because the game has promise, but I can't see suitable growth or longetivity in the future, simply because of the lack of professionalism.

Long story short:

Pros -

*Old-school flavor
*Interesting maps to explore
*Addictive gameplay
*Consistent updates
*Helpful and friendly player-base
*Balanced cash shop

Cons -

*No animations (as of yet)
*Clunky movement
*Little variation between different skills
*Repetitive, mindless quests
*Unprofessional and power abusive mods
*Immature management

Playing RPG MO is like grinding away on one of your old nostalgic MMO's, all the while a rag-tag crew of fragile-egoed toddlers are in control of your account's fate.

Do you remember the first time you played Runescape? Way back when around 2006? Do you remember booting it up, creating your character and diving into a world of mystery and wonder? RPG MO laughs and says, go. Be free. Do whatever foolish or amazing things you want. Kill a cow with magic. Cut a wizard down with the axe you forged with your own hands.

This is a tricky one to write about. In the end, I'm giving it a thumbs-down.

Absolutely everything possible if you're willing to devote the time? Your own private island? Farming and fishing? Olden-tymie graphics? Free-fer-realsies? On paper, this is my perfect game.

Unfortunately, the whole game feels like it's been dragged out of some boarded-up back closet and forced into daylight. The graphics lack charm and look like something your kid cousin made back in '94 that have been repurposed on the cheap. The UI is so, so terribad. The community has some bright shining spots, but in general... well, you're getting the kind of people who'd play a game like this for multiple years and share a laugh over taking their computers into their bathroom as to utterly optimize double xp hours. Ha. Ha ha. Uh. Yeeeaah.

As for the grind -- hey, they're real up-front about it being grind-tastic, and they sure aren't kidding. A small and tame example: I wanted to build a house on my island because, hello, a house on my island. Each square of floor requires 300 logs. Your maximum capacity, between inventory and pets, is 55. There is a set rate/speed at which chopping can be attempted, and a high chance of failing to score yourself a single log. There is also a hike between where you can chop trees and where you can stash the logs for future building.

This is also one of the lowest tier woods and one that's easily accessible. We're not even talking walls and furniture yet.

I'm sorry, RPG MO. I promise I really tried to love you.

Alright, so if you've read the other comments about this game, you're going to notice one glaring fault that predominates most of the negative comments:  The mods are Nazis and will mute or ban your account at the slightest provocation, almost seeming to exist solely to torment you and make your life a living hell.

In almost 30 hours of gameplay, I have not seen this happen once.

I have seen people have their messages removed by a moderator.  These people broke the chat rules by posting profanity in EN chat or talking about other games, both explicitly big no-nos.  They asked for it.  What the moderators DIDN'T do is mute them or ban their accounts, instead erasing only the offending messages and warning the violator that what they posted isn't acceptable.

In other words, they did their jobs.

I have also seen these same moderators answering questions from newer players, farming items and offering to sell them at reasonable prices to new players to help them get their feet on the ground, offering to forge beginner equipment for people (sometimes free of charge), and otherwise being very helpful people.  The same can be said for most of the other players.  Overall, if you ask a question, you'll get a reasonable response, even if that response is to check the wiki (why wouldn't you?  It's a great source of information!)  Sometimes, the best way to respond to a question is to refer people to an outside source of information that answers that question, as well as the other couple of dozen frequently asked questions people might have about the game.  Answering questions one at a time doesn't teach people how to help themselves, it just teaches them to rely on other people, right?

Now, the downside...it's grindy.  Very grindy.  Runescape-level grindy.  If you like that, you're in for some fun.  If you don't like it, you're going to hate this game.  I personally don't mind it, it gives me something to do to pass the time, and there's a sense of accomplishment in finishing a goal in the game that's very satisfying.

Just started playing this game, about 3 hours in as of this review. I have to say, this game is rather addicting, I can't seem to stop playing! Right when you start, If you've ever played Utlima or Runescape Classic, you get THAT kind of nostalgic feel from it. I knew I would like this game the moment I played it because Runescape Classic was fun as well, although I never played Ultima before. Currently, there are 15 skills you can level up, all of which have NO level cap. However, the SOFT cap is 120, meaning 120 is basically a practical maximum, but no absolute, so you CAN have say 200 mining potentially, but it would take a really long time as anything past the soft cap is pretty hard to obtain.

Starting the tutorial, it looked really close together, and the text i couldn't really focus on with everything else around me. Hopefully that gets refurbished soon. But the tutorial explains mostly everything considered you actually paid attention. One thing I don't believe they explain much are the shops around RPG MO. In the starting town, Dorpat, there are a number of vendors you can sell your items to. But beware, these vendors only buy low-level types of things. So, low level fish, low level weapons you forge, etc. To sell other types of items you can either click on your chest (bank), and then the market to sell your items. Or you could move to the other towns in RPG MO, where the npc's buy higher leveled items.

If you want to make money fast right when you start this game, I suggest mining/forging once you get to the iron stage (not very high ) you can sell iron helmets and make around 200k in an hour (considering you successfully make them with a high chance, and not fail most of the time.) With Iron, (like Runescape) There is a chance they do not get forged into bars. Fishing is okay, but at a high level. You could try your chances and sell your fish in the market.

I saw some negative reviews about people being banned because they posted some things in the chat. There are about 5 types of chat. All you really need to know is EN (English) is the PG chat, meaning no language, no talking about other games, and more. Try using the ST (Steam) chat, or /join 18 for the 18+ chat. It's not my fault you didn't read the rules, or the tips that appear throughout the game.

The games virtual currency, MOS can be bought or earned (in extremely low quanities) from quests. MOS can be used to buy all types of goodies in the MOS shop. One of the most used items is the 2x EXP, which cost $5 and yields 30 minutes of EXP. Ever since the steam release there has been a LOT of this stuff bought, even 10 hours at a time. Usually when one gets going, people add on to it and it builds up. So take advantage, play now!

tl;dr: Old school game is awesome, nice community. I recommend this game, 8/10.

A game with limited potential, RPG MO is ruined by two simple things.

1. Antibotting:  The nature of the captcha system vs. the nature of this game.  It encourages you to go afk by automatically crafting/fishing/cooking/etc. without repeated clicks.  So when you go afk to do something in real life, the captcha system comes up and tells you you'll be banned.  It's one of the worst mistakes such a crappy little game can make, and I cannot support them in making it.

2. Powertrippers:  I'm not sure why, but every chat room is filled with unrealistically pompous moderators.  People with their heads so far up their own asses that they threaten 50% of the playerbase every time I look at the chat.  I chose not to get involved with them, but it was quite enough to watch the way they treated new players.

If they fix these two issues, this grindy little game could take up far more of my time.  These two issues have been so for ***THREE*** years, so don't hold your breath.  That number is not made up... This is an old game that refuses to improve and gets a thumbs down from me.

This game takes the concept of grinding far beyond the celestial realm of grinding as you have already known it to exist in other games. It is exceptionally more grindy than it initially leads you to believe; you're lured in with skills that level very, very quickly because of the constant double experience time that freemium players pay for. Seriously, someone just paid for 26 hours of 2x exp - $420 worth. There is a massive plateau from about combat level 50 to combat level 100, at the very least, where the seemingly efficient way to gain any money or combat XP is to farm Efreet spawns. They're high leveled but drop the illustrious Efreet 'pet', which can be sold on the market for about $400k gold. Unfortunately, they have a 0.25% drop rate, like practically everything else in the game.

The creators of RPG-MO are sadistic in their pursuit to make you grind and grind and grind your life away to get that one Efreet pet, or that one Paladin Shield, or that one ____ (any item). In other traditional RPGs, a high level skill like mining or forging should yield a steady income of gold that increases in proportion to the level. RPG-MO works on a leveling system that exponentially makes leveling harder while providing minimal, if even at all, positive gains. Want to be a high level forger and make sapphire weapons? That sounds great! You only need 60 forging, but how are you going to get to the azurite ore if the only two azurite spots in the game are guarded by level 150 mobs? The sad part is – sapphire isn't even high tier weaponry. And if you finally do survive long enough to start smelting azurite bars into sapphire weaponry? Well, the game has such horrid 'success rates' for most forged items that you're probably going to waste most of the bars you just painstakingly made. And if you do manage to make a sapphire sword? You get just about the same XP as if you had made a lower-tier steel sword.

Ultimately, I don't recommend this game until the creators make all the drop rates much, much more tolerable. Once you hit about combat level 60, the game becomes frustratingly hard to make any sort of vertical progress in terms of new gear... unless you farm Efreets. But even if you're farming Efreets, good luck with that 0.25% drop rate!

Sorry, but to me, this game is complete boredom, but hey, maybe you like it this way!

The only way to get your health back is to eat food, which when you start is few and far between. Someone in game said something about sleeping in a bed, which was not helpful at all. Or if you have plenty of time and don't mind just standing on the same tile for ever, your health will very slowly return 1hp a minute.

There is very little animation here, you char is basically a stick figure that never changes. Walking or doing anything else for that matter all uses the exact same unchanging image. You do get a few choices to alter the head, facial hair, chest and lower body, basically just different colours. But so small a choice that it is impossible to differentiate between players. It's like half a dozen choices as to what chars look like and several of each onscreen at the same time. The only way to find who you’re looking for is to hold the mouse over each player until you find the right name. By default, player names are not visible until you mouse over the character. Unknown if you can make this info display all the time.

Magic seems overly complicated. Equip a magic pouch; install temporary spells in to said book.

Using the bank is functional but rather complicated. Find a chest; it has to be a special type of non-reward chest. Once you open it, it displays all items in it as well as what you are holding (weird), Select an item, then decide if you are placing it in the bank or removing it. Drag and drop would be a better system IMO.

Collecting resources is slow and grindy. For example, equip an axe, click on a tree then wait for you inventory to fill up, no stacking at all in the game. Run to the bank (remember it's a chest), store your items, run back to the tree, repeat until you get bored with that, then go mining and do it all over again for rocks. Or, maybe you want to make a potion, go digging up sand, take it to a forge to convert it to a vial, never discovered how to actually get any further than the part. And keep in mind that initially whilst collecting resources there is a very high failure rate. Good thing about the fail rate is you don't need to take any action to try again, it just keeps collect until your inventory is full.

Chatting is almost impossible. At times, depending on how many people are playing, text will scroll too fast to be able to keep track of anything. So if you decide to ask a question in game because you are stuck on something, you may or may not get an answer because other players may not see your question or they may just not reply. Usually they do. It is possible to make a private chat section, but I found no way to add other players. Also by default, all text is displayed until you filter out unwanted sections.

If you like trying to figure out things like this via trial and error, waiting for things to happen, and grinding like there is no tomorrow then go ahead and try the game you might like it.

Yes, it is early access, so hopefully it will improve. But for me, I doubt I will play it much in its current state, but will check on it from time to time as it seems like it has potential!

RPG MO is a old school style RPG made into a MMO. This game bring back memory’s of playing RPG's on the NES for hours on end loosing all track of time. It has a in-depth crafting, breeding, farming and fishing system that in it self you could spend months on alone. I said it reminded me of RPG's on the NES but it is not a RPG, its a straight MMO grinder with no story. So if your looking for RPG elements or depth you wont find it here.

Its still in beta but very far along and the developers are working consistently on it. There are a few things that might turn people off of it and that is that it is a extremely heavy grinding game in all areas including crafting. I personally like this type of game but not all will.

Also the chat is heavily moderated and in some chat channels like EN (the under 18 / PG / new player chat), there are rules that must be followed and most are not used to this type of moderation in a game. But the moderators are friendly and fair but do stick to the letter of the law (rules). There are other channels that are more laxly moderated. So if you do play this game take a few minutes to look over the rules as it will save some aggravation for you and everyone else.

I like this game for what it is, a basic grinder with a friendly community to waste some hours on here and there. If grinding your life away is your style you might like it as well. Be warned though if you do start playing and have to be somewhere set a alarm because hours can pass before you know it.

- There is no such thing as Local/World/Global chat yet. So yes, the chat is always clogged up even if you turn on filters. Might as well made seperate chat tabs for system notifications+game events, and player chat. Especially when you want to private message a friend because it's almost impossible to follow a private message conversation.

- As of this current review, there are six worlds (Servers). They all basically share the same chat, so you can see whatever someone is saying if they are in world one even though you are in world six. They need a Local/World/Global chat soon, the chat is getting more and more cluttered and spammy the more players that play.

- No guild system and even if there was, there isn't enough things that a guild can really do together really.

- There is a captcha system in the game. You have to fill out the captcha whenever you are actively grinding a skill every once in a while. Missing or getting the captcha wrong at least five times (Or more depending on your captcha points.) can get you jailed in-game, or instead banned. This is a anti-botting system, it's fine since the captcha does give you bonus exp. Warning, the captcha can still appear in-game even if you go cook something on the stove or take a dump on the toilet. Happened to me once.
(Maybe try telling the moderators that your eyes are bad and they'll let you off with some kind of alternative system for anti-botting.)

- No animations or voice files for character, NPCs, or monsters. Suggest playing this game while doing other things so you can just play this game like an idle game. Like any other idle game, do other things while playing since you aren't really going to see much happening other than the feeling of progress.

- Suggest if you're not going to do other things while playing, try playing your own music while muting the game. Helps to get your mind to feel better rather than just looking at a screen that isn't really changing other than scenery and the occasional watching someone die.

- I don't reccomend this game if you're not going to, or try to put 168 or more hours into it. Game is very grindy once reaching Combat Level 35+, and you will need to spend a lot of time on other skills other than combat to make money for equipment, or either invest into skilling to make equipment. If you're too lazy to invest time to make your own equipment and items, it also takes time to make money to buy higher level equipment to kill those stronger monsters.
Grindy game that does award you for doing it, but only play if you're into grindy games where it takes longer and longer to level up a skill the further you go into it. Suggest using $5 irl to buy a double exp potion.

____

Random good stuff-:

Good game to play while-
Watching favorite Youtubers, watching streams on Twitch, playing other games while you afk grind on RPG MO (Checking back every 4-6 minutes to do anti-bot captcha.), watching TV, playing another afk grind game (lol), bored.

RPG MO has a good amount of skill sets. Each of which either help you in combat in some way, or either helps you earn money to buy stuff to help you in combat.

Game does not have a very large learning curve skill. The difference between a bad and good player is depends on if they have studied the Wiki and know how to do the various things this game offers, and also knows how combat stats work. Now all you have to do is pray to RNGsus. RNGsus is your friend once you have the equipment you want for your current level.

Community is good, but currently mainly because there are many new players and most players combat levels 20+ are giving advice and giving them the ropes. Don't know how it will look later on, strict chat rules kind of ruins the fun for those of us who mainly see a chat box as a way of entertainment if you know what I mean. (Kind of cried when I got muted when I named Dark Shrooms, Dank Shrooms. There is even a quest that says to go out an find Dark Shrooms. Too bad can't get my profit selling my Shrooms.)

Skills so far do make it feel like you are progressing slowly but surely into end game. The more time you invest into the game, the more godly you feel. Tfw when you make your first Iron Broadsword and feel like a badass walking around with it, especially once you hit your first 6-8 points of damage on an enemy. Or when a monster the exact same level as you deals zero damage every 2-3 turns (Yes, there is real time action turn based combat.).

Real time action turn based combat, nostalgia for those oldschool RPGers. You can only run away from a fight three turns into a fight. Be wary of aggroing an aggressive monster that is stronger than you that can engage and lock you into combat.

____

Things I am waiting for:

I don't know, but magic feels somewhat bland. Maybe it'd be nice to have a spell that has a long cooldown, but is able to stun the target to miss 1-2 turns. Although that might be a bit overpowered for PvP so I don't know.

Still waiting for an archery combat system, although I don't know what it would exactly be like. Making you can engage combat two tiles away from a monster, and each tile the monster moves towards you counts as one turn? (You can't move when you engage combat, but you at least get 1-2 turns of free hits on enemy. Which can give an advantage in combat when you wear non-heavily armored equipment.)

Make monsters be able to move around in a set distance. Such as maybe being able to wander a distance of 4-6 tiles away from their spawn point. Would at least make the game more dynamic, and wouldn't really change much no?

It'd be nice that while fishing, you can set what actual kind of fish you want to catch. Only if you are already able to catch that fish. Catch rate/failure still apply on that fish. In advance, you could also maybe only be able to set it on the fish if you have a 40%+ chance to catch it already (Stops people from grinding higher level fish that is hard to catch for their fishing level.)

In my 40 years of gaming I have seen titles come and go. Both independent publishing and Mega productions that promise to change the face of the gaming as we know it. With baited breath I look now to an indie browser rpgmmo called RPG MO.

While my time in game, (RPG MO) has been somewhat limited; I find myself transported back through time to an age where my favorite titles consumed every free moment I could spare. Dragon Warrior-(NES), Telengard – (Atari 800XL), and of course the vaunted Ultima series from the original pc days all comes to mind when playing RPG MO.  The magic these games held was partially due to the love of the, “Grind”. That love has been neatly re-created in this polished offering from the RPG MO team.

The love and care the Dev team along with the staff has put into this offering can clearly be seen from the moment a new player steps into the tutorial. A deep crafting system along with applicable time sinks to farm materials makes for endless hours of enjoyable reminiscence. This has taken many aspects of the past and improved them to fit for today’s discerning gamer!

This game is well worth a look for just the community alone. The staff and players are both informative and well behaved. I don’t have to tell you just how rare that is these days…

The verdict!

If you are a fan of fast paced instant gratification with no community save the smell of your own stench, stay away! This game in many aspects will not speak to you.

If you are a fan of retro gaming, a helpful and friendly community along with the beauty of a smoldering slow satisfying grind, then welcome my friend!

Hands down this is a title that is welcome and I am glad I have the chance to play it!

The game is mediocre at best. Its only real selling point is that you can play it on any computer/phone with a very unstable connection.

The game requires zero skill. You click something, and then combat just takes place. You can't affect the outcome of combat at all, outside of the double-hit trick and running away and healing. This reduces the game to a pure grind game. Just with a super low skill-ceiling.

I will also commend the developers for making the shop not-P2W. The gear that you can craft/farm are comparable to the gear that you can buy in the shop.

If you're looking for a pure time sink game that doesn't challenge you in any way, then this might be the right game for you.

Also keep in mind that the game's moderators are super sensitive. Its like coming to a small town and talking to someone at the local bar: Everyone assumes you're up to no good, and if you question someone's conclusions, then everybody gangs up on you.

So I figured I wanted to play a new game for the new year and chose RPG MO since it reminded me so much of Ultima Online, Runscape and Tibia.

Started out with the tutorial in the morning December 31 with a 15 minutes 2x experience buff and got to combat level 12 with accuracy and health fighting rats and dummies (the only enemies on tutorial island), leveled my fishing to level 10, got myself a full set of bronze armor set (leveling both mining and forging to 20), ended the tutorial and went to work.

Got home again and leveled my mining some more and got hit by another 30 minutes of 2x experience buff. Kept leveling mining like mad until someone mentioned that leveling defense and magic was the most powerful (but expedience) way to do damage. So using the experience buff to my advantage I made an alt and started to train defense and magic. Then midnight came. God were I happy. 24 hours of double experience gain was a heaven sent gift I didn't know I wanted. Kept playing until five in the morning, slept for two hours and then started playing again.

This time I made a new alt, this time focusing on power alone. The amount of damage was ridiculous so I kept leveling this alt instead. Figuring that I needed food for easier health regeneration I started fishing and cooking. Started out this alt with no skills leveled like the other two I began fishing with a fishing pole, went with a fishing net once I hit level 5, changed again when I hit level 35 for a fishing cage. My is fishing easy to level up with experience buff. Before I knew it I hit level 50 and went for a wooden harpoon. Played for another four hours before I needed proper sleep.

Two days later as I'm writing this I'm testing my limits by using yet another alt that is leveled up equally in all the combat stats (magic excluded) which I've heard isn't the best way to level, but I don't care, I do what I want. This alt is also still on the tutorial island smacking at rats farming for Quest Repeat Permissions.

TL;DR: I like this game and *captcha*

You get captchas randomly and if you miss 5 in a row, you get permabanned so you can't just afk while you collect resources slower than mollasses. Early Access Review

Pretty basic grinder game (as in, you click, character performs action, you level up, click new things.) Good time waster.

Community is pretty good. Questions usually get an answer in the EN chat. Just remember that a large amount of questions can be answered using the in-game wiki - Learn how to use it and it'll help a lot.


Main reason I'm writing this is because I'm a little annoyed about the most common complaint - Mods.
EN (One of the default chats) chat has strict rules - No swearing, and no discussing other games. So people get muted(and eventually banned) there. I haven't seen the mods even mute someone before giving at least one warning.

The ST chat (one of the steam default chats, though any player can access it AFAIK) doesn't have those rules. No spamming is basically the only one there.


Not really pay to win. You can get equipment faster with money, but at most levels (including the top levels) there is a non-purchasable item that's the same (usually 2-3 stat points higher) anyways. And you need to earn the levels to use the equipment anyways. Most of the premium stuff is sold on the player market as well.
The most common purchase is a double XP potion. When someone drinks one, the double xp applies to everyone (on all servers). There are some temporary stat boosts for the user only.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nDon't let my Steam hours fool you. I've played it more on my Chromebook browser. Anyhow I will recommend this title. Though this game is not for everyone, it's got a multitude of activities to do besides combat. Unlike in some other free-to-play MMOs. Though these activites aren't very interactive. Fishing for example; a popular thing people in this game do is cook and sell fish for money. You fish by equiping your fishing rod and walking up to a fishing hole. Then, you wait for your inventory to be filled with fish, and walk away. Eventually your fishing skill will increase, and you'll be able to catch more expensive fish. So, yes, this game is a grindfest. But, due to the areas you can visit. The rewarding level system, and many options with those activities; it feels like you're doing more then grinding most of the time. There are many skills to learn and upgrade in this game, such as mining, farming, breeding, etc. They level up the more you do them, and every now and then, a point is rewarded to you, and you may give it to what ever stat you like. A combo that works suprisingly well, as both tend to feel rewarding. The music in this game is exellent, and feels medieval. The graphics are lovely, if you're in to 2D retro graphics. The game's main flaw, is how it gets boring after you get to high leveled. Though thanks to the many play styles you can take, it has some replay ability. reviewText:
Early Access Review

I thought I would write a review to give my thoughts on a great little gem I just happened to stumble upon.

Some have likened this to UO or  Runescape.

This game is a 'learn skills as you use them' style.  You have to spend time playing the game game and using these skills in order for them to go up.  Want to be better at mining? Then mine, mine, mine.

There are a lot of different skills (Farming, Fishing, Cooking, Alchemy, Breeding, Mining, Jewelry, Carpentry, Forging, and Woodcutting.  There is no skill cap on any of these, just be prepared for the need to grind away at them to have them continue in going up.  You can make some amazing items just from farming the mats and practicing.  I actually made my own bronze armor/weapons as a lower lvl character just by spending some time mining, forging and smithing before I ran out and started killing things.

The gathering skills also provide you with the opportunity to earn money by selling them on the market to players who would rather pay for them vs gathering them on their own.  I made 60k pretty quickly selling sand and purchased my pet day 1.

There is a wide varity of pets which helps to increase your inventory size as well as adding some stats to your character.  They are limited in use by your stats/level so make sure you can use one before spending money on them.

Death happens.... In this game when you die you keep 2 items (based on their vendor value) and your pet.  The rest dissapear forever.  thankfully you shouldnt die unless you just aren't paying attention or you try to tackle something way beyond your means.  There is a potion (rare drop or ingame purchase) that you can buy which will protect 5 more items for those who feel the need.  Over all death isn't something one should fear after they quickly learn how to avoid it.

The community is a great one also.  Most will share their wisdom and will come help you if you got trapped by some high level monsters while farming goods.

The game has a captcha feature pops up occasionally.  enter the correct code and get 1 point which can be spent for exp on any skill or stat.  Get it wrong no point.  Don't answer it in 180 seconds and you get a - point.  Get 5 of those and you get jailed.  This is done to help prevent botting / farming.  It has a built in system to reward you for being there and for punishing those who would use it just to farm for other accounts.

The game has a built in currency (MOS) and store which isn't a bad system.  It doesn't feel like a pay to win game.  The items are helpful but not needed.  Most things can be gotten through the market and in game gold.  The only major item in the MOS store is the 2x exp potions which gives everyone on the server 30 mins bonus experience on all skills used during that time.

Overall the game is fun.  I have 2 monitors and watch movies on one screen and paly on the other.  You can also play on your phone or any tablet/ipad (which makes work playing possible too).


I would say give this game a go and tell your friends :)

OVERVIEW:
RPG MO is an isometric, crafting based MMORPG with retro style graphics and a decent sized world; it's very similar to Runescape but not nearly as large.  Players may move using WASD, the arrow keys, or with the click of their mouse along a diagonal grid; the game's world.  Though the game is in  its infant stage, the crafting system and skills are quite in-depth, however, its combat skills are lukewarm at best, for now.

DETAILED ANALYSIS:

GAMEPLAY:
Tutorial:

It is important to know that the doorways on Tutorial Island are a one-way trip, so it would be wise to learn what each room has to teach before advancing; although you can still find the skill trainers in the starting town.  Each trainer teaches you the basics of combat, mining, woodcutting, fishing, forging, jewelry, cooking, and alchemy.

Combat:

RPG MO's combat system is currently its Achilles heel.  To engage in combat, for a first strike, players must maneuver their characters as though they are trying to move on the exact space their target is positioned on (monsters do not move); however, moving to a space adjacent to an aggressive monster will also initiate combat but with the monster dealing the first strike.  Once combat is initiated, players cannot run until at least three attacks are exchanged.  While there is a plethora of various weapon types, the only difference between them is the amount of accuracy and strength they add, as well as their handedness; there is absolutely no difference in attack speed between any weapon or combat style.

Gathering/Crafting:

There are 4 gathering skills and 6 crafting skills, most of which can be done while AFK; however, you still need to keep one eye glued to the game screen to prevent the possibility of being AFK jailed via captcha.  Most gathering skills will help for gathering their respective loot faster as they level, so a higher mining level yields quicker mining.  Similarly, crafting skills also yield more loot as they level but instead by reducing the failure chances, at least on most of them.

Loot:

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is HIGHLY addicting. If you can get past the clunky interface and the lacking visuals then you are in for a wild ride. From the beginning you have a nice tutorial to teach you about the game. It goes through all the basics. After that you are put into the world with a single starting quest of killing chicken. This is where the game opens up to you.

You can do anything at this point. Want to be a fisher? Go ahead! Want to become a fierce warrior who is feared throughout all the world? Good luck! Want to simply make jewelry and other useful items? You bet your ♥♥♥ you can do that.

The game offers so many appealing choices. No one is forced into anything. You can be killing monsters one moment then fishing for fish the next. This is truly a sandbox MMO.

That's not even the best part of the game. The small community the game has gathered is AMAZING. Everyone is helpful and the mods are quick to help anyone in need. You can have some fun conversations with people and even make some friends.

In conclusion, if you can get over the games clunky interface and lack of visuals then this will be a memorable experience for you. This gets a 9/10 for me. It will be a 10/10 when they add some animations and stuff >:)

Early Access Review

What drew me into the game was the comparison of RS and UO which were both games I thoroughly enjoyed in the past growing up. Realized quickly that this game has absolutely nothing even remotely close to being like UO.

I would normally recommend this game as it's F2P, but it's got some astonishing flaws for a game that has been in development for 3 years. As for some of the things I liked. Gathering actually holds value in this game even at the very beginning which helps boost you up to being able to do more things quicker. There's a decent anti-bot system in place. The tutorial did not explain much which thankfully there is a built-in wiki that will constantly be holding your hand through majority of the first few hours.

As for the flaws. The game is built on an isometric map with 8-bit sprites that aren't animated whatsoever. Combat is clunky and all based on RNG. First few hours you'll be constantly in the wiki learning the basics of the game, which the game has a tutorial it just skips over the most important part of the ENTIRE crafting aspect. The game is free but has an item shop built purely for people to get mid-to-late game gear with just a few dollars. There's also packages that give you a large amount of coins, housing material, rare pets, etc. After seeing the item shop I checked out how often the game is updated and it's not surprising that they spread out updates several months in between.


TL:DR It's an old school RS clone with a crafting system similar to Minecraft with the added breeding of animals and the ability to purchase your own island and build on it. Fair warning it's a F2P so be weary that it's extremely pay to win. If that sounds appealing feel free to go nuts you'll probably spend 10-20 hours before uninstalling.
